data.title: Don't convert paths to real paths when building text buffers
data.body:
Refs https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/9879
Refs https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/10856
Refs https://github.com/atom/text-buffer/pull/182
Refs https://github.com/facebook/nuclide/issues/697

/cc @dirk-thomas I have talked to some others on our team, and reconsidered this problem. I feel really bad for the delay in resolving this issue, and all of the work that you've done to propose solutions.

Where we stand right now, we think that the right solution is probably to simply remove the conversion to real paths. There may be some breakage of community packages, but it's hard for me to see how.

Please let me know what you think.

Discussed this with @nathansobo
/cc @noseglid because you maintain `atom-build` and this relates to https://github.com/noseglid/atom-build/issues/245

data.title: Yaml code block doesn't end with ``` in editor in Markdown file
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

When editing a markdown file and inserting a yaml code block (```yaml), ending the block with ``` doesn't appear to stop the Yaml parsing for the remainder of the document. Markdown preview/output is not effected, and shows correctly. Syntax highlighting for content below the closing ``` still shows Yaml formatting though.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Create a markdown file
2. Write some content. Add a ```yaml <yaml goes here> ``` block. Write more text after the yaml, maybe even another code block for some other format.
3. View the content below the close of the yaml block.

**Expected behavior:** The yaml syntax highlighting for the yaml block will end with the ``` closing element.

**Actual behavior:** The yaml syntax highlighting continues below the code block closing ```.

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions

Mac OS 10.12.2
Atom 1.12.7

### Additional Information

Note that the Markdown preview correctly shows output that matches the expected behavior of the yaml block closing.

data.title: Upgrade atom-keymap to fix issues with multiple layouts on Linux
Select to beginning or end of word in macOS Sierra save dialog not working
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Atom is not respecting the system keybinding for select to the beginning or end of word (shift+option+left arrow/right arrow) in macOS Sierra save dialog boxes.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Create a new blank document or open an existing one.
2. Choose File > Save As… 
3. Enter a multi-word file name in the Save As: field and use shift+option+left arrow or shift+option+right arrow to attempt to select individual words in the file name.

**Expected behavior:** The preceding or proceeding word should be selected.

**Actual behavior:** Atom invokes the Selection > Select to Beginning of Word/Select to End of Word menu item.

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions

Atom    : 1.12.8
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

apm  1.12.9
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5
python 2.7.10
git 2.7.2

OS: macOS Sierra 10.12.2 (16C67)

### Additional Information

This issue happens in both states of the expanded or non-expanded state of the macOS Sierra save dialog.

data.title: Cursor::getPixelRect calls deprecated TextEditor::pixelRectForScreenRange
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

`Cursor::getPixelRect` calls deprecated `TextEditor::pixelRectForScreenRange`. Causing a deprecation warning in latest Atom Beta 1.13.0-beta9.

`This is now a view method. Call TextEditorElement::pixelRectForScreenRange instead.`

### Steps to Reproduce

Use the color-picker plugin on latest beta, check deprecation warnings.  Throws this call stack in the warning:

```
TextEditor.pixelRectForScreenRange - /Applications/Atom Beta.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/src/text-editor.js:3559:12
Cursor.getPixelRect - /Applications/Atom Beta.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/src/cursor.js:675:26
```

I'm sure this happens in other plugins, this just happens to be the one that shows it for me.

### Versions

Atom    : 1.13.0-beta9
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

OS X El Capitan 10.11.6 (15G1212)

data.title: Open Window doesn't appear unless you a window in atom already open
data.body:
### Description

Open Window doesn't appear unless you a window in atom already open

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open Atom
2. Close all windows, do not quit the application
3. Go to the File Menu and click on Open

**Expected behavior:** A window to open up allowing me to select a file/folder to open in Atom

**Actual behavior:** Nothing

**Reproduces how often:** Always

### Versions

Atom    : 1.12.8
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

macOS: 10.12.2 Build 16C67

### Additional Information

This is on a fresh install of macOS. Also the Open Window does appear but only when you have a window in Atom already open.

data.title: Call debounced cursor blink resume callback any time the cursor moves
data.body: Previously, we were only calling the debounced resume callback when the cursor was already blinking, but this meant we didn't renew the debounce window. This in turn meant we attempted to start blinking the cursor again every 100ms regardless of cursor interactions, which was consuming an extra frame and causing cursor movement to not feel smooth.

data.title: Atom can't save over hidden files
data.body:
### Info
**OS:** Windows 10 64-bit
**Atom Version:** 1.12.8

### Description
Atom can't save over hidden files

I have some hidden files (.js .css etc..) I'm able to open and edit them but once I try to save changes I get a message saying: **"Unable to save file <path to my file> - EPERM: operation not permitted, open  <path to my file>"**

the files are just hidden and NOT set to "Read-only", once I unhide the file I can save it just fine.

### Steps to Reproduce
Under Windows OS
1. create or open a file with whatever file extension
2. right click the file and choose **Properties** from the context menu
3. check the option **Hidden** and apply/OK
4. open the file in atom and make some changes
5. try saving the file through **File > Save** or **ctrl + s** and an error message will appear and changes will not be saved

data.title: release update shows wrong version on about page
data.body:
Hello,

Today Atom got an update and I noticed the version wasn't showing correct.
It shows the current version on top right under ATOM and in the little box with the 'restart and install' button it says 'new update [current version]' instead of 'new update [new version]' .
![atomversion](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5873080/21635781/cd6f6476-d25f-11e6-8c39-3105a1815545.png)
In safemode the update is already installed which is odd because I hadnt accepted it yet.
I can not reproduce this at this time becouse atom is already updated, but I can imagine this happens every patch like it has before.

data.title: Fixing Install issue for linux redhat distro
data.body:
### Requirements

Tested on Centos.  the logic before tried to use || for or, but seems to return false for redhat distros, changed statement based on doc here: https://fedoraproject.org/wiki/Packaging:DistTag.  I am new to the build script logic.  @as-cii  @iolsen  can you take a look?  It's working for me on a clean install of centos on VM. 

/cc @philwyett-hemi since I'm modifying the logic that was merged.


### Description of the Change

Change logic in if statement for require for redhat distro.

### Alternate Designs

N/A

### Why Should This Be In Core?

This is currently breaking for Centos and Redhat users.

### Benefits

Fixes issue with installing on centos and redhat.



### Possible Drawbacks

N/A, after the last change this is already broken.

see comments in https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/13421

### Applicable Issues

https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/13417

data.title: Error: nothing provides libXss1 needed by atom-1.12.8-0.1.x86_64
data.body:
Hi,

It seems like you've patched one problem, only to expose yet another with the release of Atom 1.12.8. As while you may have fixed a CentOS dependency issue there's a new Fedora dependency issue. Trying to install Atom 1.12.8 with Fedora's DNF package manager (namely on Fedora 25) gave the error:

```bash
Last metadata expiration check: 1:00:11 ago on Wed Jan  4 07:13:30 2017.
Error: nothing provides libXss1 needed by atom-1.12.8-0.1.x86_64
(try to add '--allowerasing' to command line to replace conflicting packages)
```

Thanks for your time,
Brenton

data.title: Atom not remembering last state
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * [X] Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * [X] Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * [X] Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * [X] Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * [X] Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

I want that Atom remembers the last opened session. Basically what the package save-session does: https://atom.io/packages/save-session However, it says the package is deprecated since it is already included in core. But the functionality is not working in my Atom version. In this tutorial it seems to work: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IgSW1umKrVs&index=7&list=PLYzJdSdNWNqwNWlxz7bvu-lOYR0CFWQ4I However, not on my machine.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. open random file in Atom
2. close Atom
3. Reopen Atom from macOS dock

**Expected behavior:** Atom should reopen the last opened folders and tabs.

**Actual behavior:** New empty tab is opened (if "open empty editor on start" is activated) or nothing is opened at all (else).

**Reproduces how often:**  100 %

### Versions

Atom    : 1.12.7
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

macOS Sierra 10.12.2 (16C67)

data.title: Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property '0' of undefined
data.body:
[Enter steps to reproduce below:]

1. create a new branch, add a file to it
2. checkout master and merge the new branch
that's it!

**Atom Version**: 2.2.1
**Electron Version**: 1.3.6
**System**: Mac OS X 10.12.2
**Thrown From**: Atom Core


### Stack Trace

Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property '0' of undefined

```
At /Applications/Learn IDE.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/node_modules/learn-term.js/src/term.js:1306

TypeError: Cannot read property '0' of undefined
    at TerminalWrapper.Terminal.refresh (/Applications/Learn IDE.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/node_modules/learn-term.js/src/term.js:1306:18)
    at TerminalWrapper.Terminal._cursorBlink (/Applications/Learn IDE.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/node_modules/learn-term.js/src/term.js:1422:8)
    at _blinker (/Applications/Learn IDE.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/node_modules/learn-term.js/src/term.js:1439:10)
```

### Commands

```
     -9:46.2.0 core:paste (atom-workspace.workspace.scrollbars-visible-when-scrolling.theme-one-dark-syntax.theme-one-dark-ui)
  2x -9:45 learn-ide:paste (div.terminal)
     -9:28.6.0 core:paste (atom-workspace.workspace.scrollbars-visible-when-scrolling.theme-one-dark-syntax.theme-one-dark-ui)

```

### Config

data.title: With PHP Inside JS Script, Throws error
data.body:
### Prerequisites * [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following: * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/ * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages ### Description When you write a php statement inside of a JavaScript statement on a .php page, it throws an error inside the IDE when there is actually no errors. Stackoverflow: [http://stackoverflow.com/questions/41433018/atom-editor-error-when-php-is-inside-javascript](url) ### Steps to Reproduce 1. Create new .PHP Page 2. Paste the following example code: (remove spaces.. code doesn't show up here) ``` < html> < head> < ?php $testvar = "Test"; ?> < script> var test = < ?php echo $testvar; ?> < /script> < /head> < body> < p> This is a test.

< /body> < /html>` ``` 3. Page Displays Correctly but the Editor IDE highlights everything else on page as an error. **Expected behavior:** Not show the red highlighted text. **Actual behavior:** Drops color on all code after the script, highlights everything in red. **Reproduces how often:** 100% ### Versions 1.12.7 ATOM, Windows 10. ### Additional Information Screenshot: http://i.imgur.com/6kc2Yob.png ![jserror](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/17038330/21595104/dd232176-d0ef-11e6-8bc2-66b565da8514.png)

data.title: Updated date range to include 2017
data.body:
### Requirements

* Filling out the template is required. Any pull request that does not include enough information to be reviewed in a timely manner may be closed at the maintainers' discretion.
* All new code requires tests to ensure against regressions

### Description of the Change

<!--Updated the license file to include 2017 in the copyright.

We must be able to understand the design of your change from this description. If we can't get a good idea of what the code will be doing from the description here, the pull request may be closed at the maintainers' discretion. Keep in mind that the maintainer reviewing this PR may not be familiar with or have worked with the code here recently, so please walk us through the concepts.

-->

### Alternate Designs

<!-- Explain what other alternates were considered and why the proposed version was selected -->
There isn't really any alternatives and the proposed version was selected to make sure that Atom keeps its copyright in the new yea.

### Why Should This Be In Core?

<!-- Explain why this functionality should be in atom/atom as opposed to a package -->
It is to protect Atom in the new year from copyright infringes. 

### Benefits

<!-- What benefits will be realized by the code change? -->
Protect Atom from copyright infringes.

### Possible Drawbacks

<!-- What are the possible side-effects or negative impacts of the code change? -->
No drawbacks.

### Applicable Issues

<!-- Enter any applicable Issues here -->
No issues.

data.title: You can't zoom Project Find Results (or settings)
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

All other windows in Atom (except for settings) respond to Ctrl+/- for zooming.  Both of these windows should already be web views, therefore I would expect them to zoom like all the other windows.  But for some reason they don't.  The fonts are too small for me to read if I can't zoom them.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Use Find in Proejct to locate things in your project
2. Try to zoom results
3. squint, curse, cry

**Expected behavior:** Text gets bigger, text becomes readable

**Actual behavior:** Nothin

**Reproduces how often:** Always

### Versions

Atom 1.12.7 on  OSX 10.11.6

data.title: Build failing - "Could not determine Electron version"
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

I would like to manage my versions of Atom via building the executable's from source, but I've been unable to successfully build anything with script/build.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Follow the instructions at [here](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/docs/build-instructions/windows.md)
2. Navigate to local Atom clone.
3. Open Administrator CMD in the script directory of the clone.
4. Execute the build script.
5. Wait for a few minutes after printing "Installing apm" on the screen.
6. The Error's will be displayed.

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]
Given NodeJS 6.9, Python 2.7, and an installed Visual Studio 2015 with Visual C++ support, Atom should build as easily on Windows as it does on Linux.

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]
*

> C:\Users\1nf0rmed\Documents\atom-master\script>build
Node:   v6.9.2
Npm:    v3.10.5
Python: v2.7.12

data.title: Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property 'hunkForOldPosition' of null
data.body:
With a fresh build of Atom from this morning (version 1.14.0-dev-5669246) I'm starting to see this error quite frequently, from various places (both from bundled and community packages):

```
pane.coffee:905 Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property 'hunkForOldPosition' of null
translateBufferPositionWithSpatialIndex @ display-layer.js:275
translateBufferPosition @ display-layer.js:261
module.exports.DisplayMarkerLayer.translateBufferPosition @ display-marker-layer.js:158
module.exports.DisplayMarker.getHeadScreenPosition @ display-marker.js:149
module.exports.Cursor.getScreenPosition @ cursor.coffee:82
module.exports.TextEditor.getCursorScreenPosition @ text-editor.coffee:2078
module.exports.TextEditor.isFoldedAtCursorRow @ text-editor.coffee:3284
module.exports.BracketMatcherView.updateMatch @ bracket-matcher-view.coffee:56
(anonymous function) @ bracket-matcher-view.coffee:1
module.exports.Emitter.simpleDispatch @ emitter.js:25
module.exports.Emitter.emit @ emitter.js:129
module.exports.TextBuffer.emitDidChangeTextEvent @ text-buffer.js:1326
module.exports.TextBuffer.transact @ text-buffer.js:844
(anonymous function) @ whitespace.js:77
module.exports.Emitter.simpleDispatch @ emitter.js:25
module.exports.Emitter.emit @ emitter.js:129
module.exports.TextBuffer.saveAs @ text-buffer.js:1056
module.exports.TextBuffer.save @ text-buffer.js:1048
module.exports.TextEditor.save @ text-editor.coffee:882
module.exports.Pane.saveItem @ pane.coffee:664
(anonymous function) @ pane.coffee:1
module.exports.Pane.saveActiveItem @ pane.coffee:639
module.exports.Workspace.saveActivePaneItem @ workspace.coffee:679
core:save @ register-default-commands.coffee:78
module.exports.CommandRegistry.handleCommandEvent @ command-registry.coffee:255
(anonymous function) @ command-registry.coffee:1
module.exports.KeymapManager.dispatchCommandEvent @ keymap-manager.js:599
module.exports.KeymapManager.handleKeyboardEvent @ keymap-manager.js:390
module.exports.WindowEventHandler.handleDocumentKeyEvent @ window-event-handler.coffee:76
(anonymous function) @ window-event-handler.coffee:1
```

I'm not sure whether this issue should have been reported here or in `text-buffer`. 

Once this error is raised once for an editor you can no longer modify it (the error keeps being raised again and again on inputs and saves). Closing and reopening the file doesn't help neither, only a reload/restart fixes it.

data.title: Usability: default theme is too low contrast and too blurry
data.body:
When I installed and opened up Atom for the first time, I was put off a bit: the default theme is too low contrast and badly readable (in my personal opinion / with my screen setup). It seems to be made mainly to look super fancy, while throwing basic readability out of the window: especially on the tabs, the text is too small, too blurry and too low contrast.

Compare this to Visual Studio Code which has a similarly nice color scheme, but unlike Atom's default colors Visual Studio Code has super crisp and high contrast text on the tabs:

![contrast_comparison](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1573352/21582240/042f260c-d050-11e6-8324-eb2f494d1b30.png)

As you can see, even the file menu is just a tad more crisp and more comfortably readable with Visual Studio Code.

Because this might give an initial bad impression (it certainly did for me) and potentially needlessly uses up people's time for altering the color scheme and fonts to something more readable, I suggest that this should be changed for a future version of Atom.

data.title: --new-window not working
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode

    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

--new-window doesn't work at all

### Steps to Reproduce

1. `atom . --new-window`
2. `atom ../another-dir --new-window`

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]
Both to open in new WINDOWS

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]
Both open in the same window but different panes/tabs

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]
100% of the time.

### Versions

```
Atom: 1.12.7
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome: 52.0.2743.82
Node: 6.5.0
apm: 1.12.9
npm: 3.10.5
node: 4.4.5
python: 2.7.13
git: 2.11.0
OS: Mac 10.12.1 (16B2659)
```

### Additional Information

I noticed before running `atom --clear-window-state` it was doing the same where it'd open in the same window but different pane but was also causing that window to go from Mac's full screen mode into normal windowed mode as if it was opening a new window.

data.title: Add dalek package to let people know when they have built-in packages installed in ~/.atom/packages
data.body:
### Description of the Change

<!--

We must be able to understand the design of your change from this description. If we can't get a good idea of what the code will be doing from the description here, the pull request may be closed at the maintainers' discretion. Keep in mind that the maintainer reviewing this PR may not be familiar with or have worked with the code here recently, so please walk us through the concepts.

-->

The [dalek package](https://github.com/atom/dalek) checks after Atom activates the initial set of packages to see if there are packages that are installed both as built-in packages and as community packages. When people install built-in packages as community packages (often to get "the latest version") because built-in packages are designed to work with a specific version of Atom, strange bugs can happen that are very hard to diagnose. The dalek packages detects this problematic situation and notifies the person running Atom, giving them the information they need to correct the situation.

### Alternate Designs

<!-- Explain what other alternates were considered and why the proposed version was selected -->

* Automatic uninstallation - discounts that there can be valid reasons for this configuration

### Why Should This Be In Core?

<!-- Explain why this functionality should be in atom/atom as opposed to a package -->

This functionality is in a package.

### Benefits

<!-- What benefits will be realized by the code change? -->

* Reduced support overhead caused by people being in this situation without knowing it can cause problems

### Possible Drawbacks

<!-- What are the possible side-effects or negative impacts of the code change? -->

* Temporarily increased support overhead caused by people learning that this is a problem

### Applicable Issues

<!-- Enter any applicable Issues here -->

Fixes https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/11090

data.title: Update languages
data.body:
### Requirements

* Filling out the template is required. Any pull request that does not include enough information to be reviewed in a timely manner may be closed at the maintainers' discretion.
* All new code requires tests to ensure against regressions

### Description of the Change

* language-c
  * Fixes an issue where lines were merged even if they weren't supposed to
  * Improves ternary expression highlighting
  * Minor code cleanup
* language-java
  * Large rewrite to how `new` is matched and tokenized
  * Fixes static initialization blocks not being recognized
* language-javascript
  * Ligature support for `!!`
  * Fixes highlighting for multiline imports
  * Unsurprisingly, more JSDoc improvements and fixes
* language-ruby
  * Remove `*.erb` files from the recognized filetypes
* language-sql
  * Add `timestamptz` as a recognized keyword
* language-yaml
  * Add `.yml.erb` and `.yaml.erb` to the recognized filetypes

### Alternate Designs

N/A

### Why Should This Be In Core?

N/A

### Benefits

See above.

### Possible Drawbacks

Possible regressions are always a possibility.  Things to look out for this time include Java tokenization regressions (especially around lines containing `new` and `static`).

### Applicable Issues

N/A

Coming up: more language-java and language-c bugfixes, as well as a giant overhaul of language-css.

data.title: Reduce the impact of leaking Editor, Selection, & Cursor objects
data.body:
It is pretty easy for 3rd party Atom packages to accidentally introduce memory leaks, causing destroyed `TextEditor` objects to be retained on the heap indefinitely. This PR updates editors and their sub-objects to do a more aggressive teardown when they are destroyed, so that leaking these objects will have a negligible impact on Atom's memory usage, even for large files.

See also https://github.com/atom/text-buffer/pull/193

🍐'd with @nathansobo

data.title: Atom not responding after hitting return key.
data.body:
The only time it seems to lock up though is on this line of code:

<!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD XHTML 1.0 Transitional/EN" "http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd">

If  I try to hit the return key to move this line of code down in atom, it locks up. No other lines (code or no code) seem to have this issue and the return key works as normal. 

Things I have tried are:
- install updates
- restarting atom
- quitting atom completely
- restarting my computer
- testing the return key on this line of code in other files (same result)

I have a base model 2015 macbook pro retina.

data.title: Bad Performance Related to Syntax Coloring
data.body:
### Prerequisites
- [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
- [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide.
### Description

When commenting long HTML lines, the editor hangs if the comment is authored in a natural way.  There is a workaround that can avoid the editor hang.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Create an HTML document with multiple long lines of HTML code.  A "long line" is defined as a line > 500KB in length.  For example, create a script tag and place the contents of a large file into it.  "Large" is defined as a file > 500KB in size.  Then create a second tag with the contents of another file.  NOTE:  you may need more HTML contents to reproduce this issue, if so simply create the code.
2. Preprend an HTML comment to the first script tag, i.e. "<!--".  The code below will be re-colored as a comment.
3. Append "-->" to the closing script tag.  The editor will hang while re-coloring the syntax.

**Expected behavior:** [What you expected to happen]
Just use the previously known coloration when closing the comment.  Why re-process?

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happened]
Editor hangs while re-coloring.
### Workaround

When commenting long lines with an HTML comment, add the closing token first, then add the opening token.  No hanging occurs.
- NOTE:  there's no reason to think this doesn't happen with long JavaScript lines commented with /\* ... */.  Although unverified there's reason to suspect this could be a general problem for any programming language with multi-line comments in AtomIDE.

### Note:  @50Wliu demanded we re-open this bug with a definition of "large" and "long line" per https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/12784#issuecomment-249675622.

### Versions

Atom    : 1.9.9
Electron: 0.37.8
Chrome  : 49.0.2623.75
Node    : 5.10.0

apm  1.10.0
npm  2.13.3
node 0.10.40
python 2.7.12
git 2.7.4

data.title: Markdown for numbered list in Issues Template
data.body:
### Description of the Change

I changed the Github Issues Template so that the numbered list uses repeating `1.` instead of incrementing numeric values.

### Alternate Designs

The current numbering scheme could still be used, but ... see *Benefits* for why I prefer not.

### Why Should This Be In Core?

This is the code repo that this specific Issues Template is used for.

### Benefits

I found that it is much easier to edit a numbered list in any Markdown document that uses repeating numbering instead of incremental numbers that represent the actual numbering that is rendered. It is much easier to add and remove any list element if repeated numbering is used. I only have to focus on the element's content and not the position that it appears in the list. Otherwise, I would have to also manually edit the numbers for any element that appears after the added/removed element. The numbering applied in the raw Markdown is ignored by the HTML renderer anyway, since it will be converted to HTML `<ol><li>`.

### Possible Drawbacks

The repeated numbering may be confusing for those less familiar with Markdown than if reading the raw Markdown code with incremental numbering. However, I would argue that the learning curve to understand how repeated numbering will be rendered is quite minimal. Markdown has become a universal documentation standard in the software world anyways.

### Applicable Issues

None that I am aware of.

### Other Notes

PRs similar to this one could potentially be applied to other projects under the **Atom** organization, such as [settings-view](https://github.com/atom/settings-view/blob/master/ISSUE_TEMPLATE.md) and [tree-view](https://github.com/atom/tree-view/blob/master/ISSUE_TEMPLATE.md).

data.title: Mac: Open dialog (CMD+O) will not appear if all windows are closed
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

The Mac **Open Dialog** (CMD+O) will not appear if all windows are closed

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open Atom in Mac
1. Close all app windows, but keep the app open
1. Trigger the Mac Open interface. You can do so by clicking on File --> Open or pressing CMD+O

**Expected behavior:** The Mac "Open Dialog" appears

**Actual behavior:** Nothing...The File menu will flash, but the Open Dialog will not appear

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions

```
➜ atom --version
Atom    : 1.12.7
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0
➜ apm --version
apm  1.12.9
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5
python 2.7.13
git 2.11.0
```

I am using `MacOS 10.12.2`. I can also comment that I have been witnessing this issue for at least a year. It was just never a blocking issue since there are workarounds (see below).

### Additional Information

The workaround is to have an app window open, in which case the Open Dialog will open without error. Or, I use the CLI to open a directory with the `atom` command.

data.title: Cursor jumps by "tabs" not spaces
data.body:
### Description

I can't get the cursor to move in the expected way when hitting the arrow keys, i.e. moving one character left and right. Instead it moves according to some idea of "tabs", which seems to be set to 2 spaces.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Type `______test` on a line,  where `_` is a space.
2. Go to start of line (cursor is at index 0, i.e. `|______test`).
3. Press right.

**Expected behavior:** cursor is at index 1, i.e. `_|_____test`.

**Actual behavior:** cursor is at index 2, i.e. `__|____test`.

**Reproduces how often:** always.

### Versions

```
% atom --version
Atom    : 1.12.7
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0
```

data.title: Upgrade find-and-replace to use new marker layer API for fast clearing of markers
data.body:
Depends on https://github.com/atom/text-buffer/pull/192
Depends on https://github.com/atom/find-and-replace/issues/835
